intro: Urtica chamaedryoides var. genuina, commonly known as the common nettle, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Urticaceae family and is characterized by its stinging hairs that cause a skin irritation when touched. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring heart-shaped leaves with serrated edges and clusters of small, greenish-white flowers. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks, and is often found in disturbed soils. Its fibrous stems and leaves are used in traditional medicine and as a source of fiber.
